nodes.text: The study tests whether conflicting color stimuli interfere with reading color names and whether conflicting word stimuli interfere with naming ink colors, and how practice affects these interference effects

Method: Stimuli combined word and color in same symbol by printing color names in inks of other colors so each trial presents simultaneous word and color stimuli; control tests used words in black and color patches in geometric figures

Method: Three experiments—(1) read color names printed in conflicting colors versus same names printed in black (RCNd vs RCNb); (2) name ink colors of words printed in conflicting colors versus name color squares (NCWd vs NC); (3) eight days practice naming ink colors of conflicting words (NCWd) measuring changes across tests

Method: Subjects were college students (various samples: 70 in Exp1, 100 in Exp2, 32 in Exp3), tests administered individually with controlled illumination and timed vocal responses; small error-correction procedure applied
Assumption: Increase in reaction time when conflicting stimulus present measures interference strength of that stimulus type upon the required response
Assumption: Differences in interference reflect relative strength of learned associations for reading words versus naming colors, traceable to differing training histories

Result (Exp 1): Reading color names printed in conflicting colors took on average 2.3 seconds longer per 100 items than reading same names in black; this 5.6 percent increase was not statistically reliable

Result (Exp 2): Naming ink colors of words printed in conflicting colors increased mean time from 63.3 s to 110.3 s for 100 items (increase 47.0 s, 74.3 percent); effect large and highly reliable (multiple standard-deviation units)

Evidence: Distributions show little overlap between NC (color squares) times and NCWd (color of printed words) times; median and histogram analysis support strong interference of word stimuli on color naming
Result: Sex differences observed—females faster than males in naming colors; practice reduced but did not eliminate this sex difference, suggesting partial acquisition through training

Conclusion: Word-reading associations are stronger and more effective than color-naming associations, accounting for asymmetric interference (word stimuli strongly interfere with color naming; color stimuli produce little interference with word reading)

Result (Exp 3): Eight days practice naming ink colors of conflicting words produced substantial improvement on the practiced NCWd test (mean gain ~33.9 percent), some transfer to naming colors in squares (~13.9 percent), increased interference when reading color words (RCNd), and increased intersubject variability on NCWd

Conclusion: Practice can reduce but not eliminate strong habitual interference; practice increased group variability when training the more difficult, less-practiced task (naming ink colors) and decreased variability when practicing the simpler, well-practiced task (reading words)

Limitation: Interference and practice effects measured with serial aloud vocal responses in college samples using a specific five-color stimulus set; generalization to other populations, modalities, or stimulus sets not established

Conclusion: The observed asymmetry in interference supports the interpretation that differential training history (much greater practice in reading words than in naming colors) largely accounts for the classic Stroop effect
